name: Ross
comment info: The moderator's comment did not explain the answer to my wonder: why monopoly and oligopoly grew so much although Americans have always opposed them? It also raises another question for me: how are these data collected? How credible are they?

replies.comment info:
HI, @Ross --
You raise three very perceptive points about this graph. 
First, You ask about oligopoly. You are right.  The graph shows oligopoly rather than monopoly, but note the headline of the original article.
Second, please do some research on the growth of oligopoly on the U. S. (and the world?).  There is are many reasons for its growth (and waning) in US history as well as a difference of opinion.
Third, to find out how the data was collected, check you the source given under the graph.  It isn't the Department of Commerce, as you may have expected.  Learn how it was collected.  What do you think of the collection method?  
Please share with us your findings and thoughts.
Thank you for being such a perceptive responder.

name: Ross
comment info: The last time there was any hot topic about anti-trust laws was 1999, when Microsoft was being accused of monopoly in browser industries. After that, for almost twenty years, we have heard so little about monopoly and oligopoly that we presume it is not a problem.This graph is truly shocking because it shows not only a few, but most industries are now dominated by oligopoly or monopoly. How can this still happen in one of the most modern and advanced economy? Who are the stakeholders?

replies.comment info:
HI, @Ross --

I replied to your response  above, but let me add her a comment.

"(M)ost industries are now dominated by oligopoly or monopoly?"  Go to the source to see their complete list and then think about which industries are included and which are not.  Why do you think these were the industries researched?

name: Ellie G
comment info: What I found most interesting in this graph was the market share differences from random companies compared to phone and technology-related corporations. This really speaks greatly to how our culture is using technology.

replies.name: R
replies.comment info: @Ellie G I totally agree with this point about how we can see the culture of technology use through this chart. Compared to all the other industries, the smartphone industries is the youngest one. However, it is also the industry with the most oligopoly market share.  Maybe there is a correlation between those two. Can concentration of market share be a trend for industries today? Since most new industries are about new technologies today, they have  very high technology barriers.

HI,@Ellie G --

Good notice.  But, I don't think these were "random" companies.  How do you think the industries were collected?  (The source listed below the graph may be helpful.)

This graph does say much about "how our culture is using technology."  How about sharing with us how you think that this graph shows how we use technology and what you think may be needed.

name: Ava D.
comment info:
It is interesting to see how different companies control the market. The one the surprises me the most is tobacco companies. It seems that two tobacco companies are controlling the market, this is likely because tobacco, as a whole, has decreased in sales. Therefore, less prominent tobacco companies are probably going out of business because they are unable to lower their prices and now more and more citizens are turning to vaping. Recently, it was announced that Altria will buy a large stake in Juul. I wonder if this is taken into account and if Altria is one of the tobacco companies that is controlling the market.

 I understand that some companies have larger share of the market, but I wonder if these sales have gone up or down since the early 2000's. This would be interesting to include on the graph. 

A good name for this graph could be "Is Sharing Caring?" I thought of this because when two companies share a large portion of the market is this beneficial to the economy overall? Or, would it be better for there to be more competition with more companies?

replies.name: C
replies.comment info: @Ava D. - That's a great title! You are very insightful in your thoughts about tobacco companies. It is interesting that the tobacco companies are buying stock in Juul.

name: Kaitlyn G
comment info: Many aspects of this graph are prominent to me.  For one, I find it interesting that the hardware stores and tobacco industries have such high market shares. name: Madison S.
comment info: This graph shows the combined market share of the two largest companies in various industries  in the early 2000s compared to today. I find it quite interesting that most of these categories have experienced growth in the market share percentage over time. I find it interesting that the early 2000s are considered to be 2002-2007 in this graph, and yet the technology companies only start from 2012. This signifies the rise of importance of technology such as smartphones and other devices which people have come to depend on. It makes sense that these categories all saw growth. However, the context of the graph must also be analyzed. The graph does not show the growth of the industry, but rather the share of the market the two largest companies of each category hold. This speaks to how the main companies have overall gained more control over the market in most recent years, making a case for people to say that large companies are beginning the approach to a near monopoly in future years. There were only five categories which experienced a decrease in market share. This exemplifies the decrease of these industries and therefore the decrease of the want to have a monopoly in them. An appropriate headline for this graph would be, "Rushing Towards Go: a Game of Approaching Monopolies in the US"

replies.comment info:
HI, @Madison S. --
Very interesting noticings and wonderings.  
I recommend that you go to the source of the data , listed below the graph.  You will find more data on more industries and how the data was collected.
Please share with us any additional insights you have.

name: Chris (Moderator)
comment info:
Hello! I am Moderator Chris.
This is my first time moderating this site. I am enjoying the comments you all are making. Also enjoying the sunshine from my patio in Tucson AZ while most of you are in the deep freeze. Stay warm and continue sending your insightful comments about "What's Going ON In This Graph"!

name: Mia D.
comment info: Personally, I find this graph to be very intriguing. I will be the first to say that I am not knowledgable (and honestly a bit lost) in the areas of stock markets, finance, etc. However, it is interesting to see how the percentage of the market that certain industries possess changed from the early 2000s to the present. For example, the tobacco industry possessed about 52% of the market in 2000, and now it has a market share of about 83%, one of the largest percentages of all industries. Back in the day, cigarettes very still prevalent. However, with the current uprising of the teenage vaping epidemic, I would say that this could be one of the main contributors to the tobacco industry's increased market share. One can also see that the smartphone industry is absolutely booming with a market share of almost 100%! Being a member of this modern technological world, it does not surprise me that the two largest smartphone companies (most likely Apple and Samsung) are making so much profit. This graph just goes to show how today's trends truly have an impact on the consumer market.

replies.name: C
replies.comment info:
@Mia D. - I agree with you that the tobacco market is probably declining. I think there are several reasons for that including the increasing popularity of vaping.
A question for you: How could you explain the fact that the market share of the the top two tobacco companies could increase their market share in a declining industry?

name: Grace B
comment info:
The graph displays the market share among two companies. The companies are in different industries. The two power companies controlling several industries seems similar to a monopoly. Some market shares increase while some decrease. The graph for the most part increases in market share over time. Some companies increase on smaller intervals while other companies decrease slowly. As the time changes, industries change with times. If industries are not inline with the time they seem to decrease and loose market share. Could the increase be because of the monopoly or the company being inline and updated with the times and new technology?  
A catchy headline could be Who is really in control of the markets?

name: MiaF
comment info: I actually enjoy this graph. It is interesting to see how powerful the top two companies in each industry truly are. I can see how smartphone companies (probably with Apple as the largest) controls so much of their particular market. By convincing the public that they need a certain type of phone to properly communicate with peers, a company can create a monopoly on their industry. Nobody likes having to text their friends with Samsungs from their iPhones for several reasons (the emojis are not in sync, one cannot leave or add someone to a group chat, the sent texts are green, etc.). Another industry with a high market share of the two largest companies is hardware stores. This is probably due to chains such as Ace and Home Depot being able to maintain low prices and still make a profit, driving out of business smaller hardware stores. I think that this is a similar situation with Tobacco companies that can lower their prices.

replies.name: D
replies.comment info: @MiaF I agree I notice how Apple and Samsung are the top selling brands now in 2019. over time they have grown and dominated.

replies.name: M
replies.comment info:
@MiaF - What a great business mind you have! Thanks for bringing your observations to the conversation.

I'm curious...what do you believe the pros and cons are of monopolies in industries such as smartphones?

replies.name: C
replies.comment info: @MiaF- This is very insightful. It seems that companies like Apple can control a big share of the market through effective advertising. I think you are correct about the large hardware stores are able to keep costs down so Home Depot is able to beat out the small "mom and pop" stores.

name: Olivia C
comment info: I notice that technology companies since 2012- in the areas of smartphones, social networks, and cellphone services- have increased their market share. I wonder if monopolies are forming. Perhaps this graph could be called, "Out with the old, In With the New," as Sharpay Evans from High School Musical sings in her song "Fabulous". Movie theaters' market shares are considerably low, perhaps due to Amazon Prime and Netflix. Although this is not a service for phones or a social network, I feel these providers should have been included under technology companies since 2012. I wonder if this graph was made to analyze the effects of net neutrality.

replies.name: D
replies.comment info: @Olivia C Haha! I am a big High School Musical fan. Netflix has truly become a reason why lots of my friends not only do not go to the movies, but also do not pay for cable tv services.

replies.name: M
replies.comment info: @Olivia C great observations about the possible implications of net neutrality! How do you think this would affect the results of the graph if at all?

name: Moderator Erica
comment info:
Clarification:

The graph does not tell us things like "is the tobacco industry growing" or "shipbuilding is becoming more popular."

This graph does help answer the question, "Within the tobacco industry are the top 2 companies taking over (gaining market share) or losing ground (losing market share)?" 

When we notice that the top 2 companies in the tire manufacturing industry are losing market share, it does not imply that tires are becoming less popular, but just that the top 2 companies are no longer dominating that industry.

In this light, what do you notice and wonder?

name: Sharon
comment info:
Welcome to Wednesday's moderation of  “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  Today’s graph shows how the market share of the top two companies in several industries, including high tech, has changed in the past 10 – 20 years.  
When too much market share to held by a very few companies in an industry, this is called a monopoly.  Does America have more monopolies now than in the past?   Why should we care?  
From 9 am – 2 pm E.T. today, give us your responses online to these three questions -- "What do you notice?",  "What do you wonder?", and  "What's going on in this graph?"  Plus, share with us a catchy headline. 
On Thursday afternoon, we’ll reveal the article that included these graphs and much more.  We look forward to reading your discoveries.
The next “What’s Going On in This Graph?” will be released tomorrow, Thursday, Jan. 31 with moderation on Wednesday, February 6.  
The topic:  Pop Music!

name: Tawfiq
comment info:
I notice that market shares for the top two companies have risen considerably in a lot of industries. This could be dangerous as it seems individual companies are growing in power and therefore sway in their respective fields of industry.

I wonder if this overall increase in power for the top two companies is good for the consumer as to me it would seem there is less competition meaning less drive for these companies to push themselves to create superior products. There is also the question of how some of these company shares are rising so quickly, are they buying out the competition?

My headline would be, “Superior products or superior tactics?”

replies.name: O
replies.comment info: @Tawfiq I agree! Using iPhones as an example, the differences between the iPhone XS and the iPhone XR are minute. The iPhone XS has: 5.8-inch OLED, 19.5:9 aspect ratio, True Tone, 2436 x 1125 pixels (458 ppi), 1,000,000:1 contrast ratio, and 82.9% screen-to-body ratio, while the similar iPhone XR has: 6.1-inch LCD, 19.5:9 aspect ratio, True Tone, 1792 x 828 pixels (326 ppi), 1,400:1 contrast ratio, and 79.0% screen-to-body ratio. Are these individual, monopolized companies, such as Apple, pushing superior products- or waiting for a payroll?

name: E & T
comment info:
We notice that airline companies are increasing in market shares while aircraft manufacturing is decreasing. 

We wonder why the tobacco company is increasing so much especially since there has been such a public push back (anti cigarettes mostly) in recent years. 
Also, why is tire manufacturing decreasing so significantly and why aircraft manufacturing is decreasing, even slightly. Planes seem too important to not be increasing at all. 

The story this graph is telling us is: Who Cares About the Seemingly Important Companies. Give More Market Shares to Hardware Stores!

replies.name: M
replies.comment info: @E & T I had the same question pertaining to tobacco because people today have moved on to smoking juuls, vapors, and cigarettes substitutes but the tobacco industry continues to have a large market share, why is that?

comment info:

Title: Thinking of starting your own business? Think again. Big bosses are back and tyrannical.

replies.comment info: @CCDMJD What leads you to believe that the top 2 companies in each industry are gaining all the shares?

name: Dakota
comment info: We noticed that Hardware Stores, Shipbuilding and Private Prisons had the largest increase in market sharesbetween the two largest companies in the respective industries. As a group we wonder why Tire manufacturing has the largest decrease in market shares between the two biggest companies in that industry. This graph could be titled “Making a Mark in Marketing”.

name: Jose
comment info:
I notice that everything is increasing in market share which mean same there’s less competition except for air craft mfg pesticides, outdoor adds , investment banking and tire mfg. 

I wonder why so many industries are increasing in market share while a few are decreasing, I wonder how the economy is impacting these changes.

name: Anon
comment info:
I noticed that in most markets the the market share is increasing. Only a few decreased, likely due to lack of demand. 
I wonder what’ll happen in the next century as technology advances and how this graph would look. 

A title is... capitalism at it’s finest

Also why are tires and aircraft manufacturing decreasing so much? As far as I know those are both very prevalent.

name: Alęx
comment info: Monopoly is no longer just a board game in your room. It’s real life. Majority of industies since 2000, have gained larger shares of the market. In the future, how much of the instusties will gain  control on the market?

replies.name: M
replies.comment info: @Alęx I love that saying. So clever and true! It truly is the trends that impact the monopolies. Power to the people, literally!

name: Sydney
comment info: We notice that although technology companies have not been around for as long, they still have more market shares than other companies. I wonder how shipbuilding has so many shares because it is not used as much.  Our title would be The Ups and Downs of Life.

replies.name: M
replies.comment info: @Sydney - Yes! Isn't that interesting that the tech companies have sprung up more recently and the top 2 companies in each of the categories listed are dominating the market. Do you think that is a good thing? Do you think it drives up prices or brings prices down?

name: SonOfDavid
comment info: We noticed that Cellphones and Hardware stores have the most shares. We wonder why Pharmacies are not higher and what is happening to Tire shares. According to the graph, for the most part, the top two companies per market have increased since 2000. The title should be: How’s Business? Booming.

name: Karen Hartless
comment info: I notice that nearly every market is growing in Market share which implies that most markets are consolidating. I wonder what is going on in the Tire manufacturing marketing that would cause the largest companies to lose market share. I would expect a decrease in market share to be due to increased competition or some kind of business disruption with the largest manufacturers which has driven their existing customers to other existing competitors. I also noticed that the top 2 smartphone manufacturers have essentially 100% of the market which could stifle future innovation. In general, the technology markets are dominated by the top 2 companies in their industry.

replies.name: M
replies.comment info: @Karen Hartless - Great observations Karen! You have some very plausible explanations for the changes you observe. There are definitely many pros and cons to consolidation versus breaking up monopolies. Thanks for your insights! Keep noticing and wondering!
